CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: For ( PCPDTBT ) , which showed absorption in the range 380-900 nm in the AM 1.5 G spectrum , good hole mobility ( 0.01 - 0.1 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ) and a high power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 3.2% with PC71BM as the electron acceptor. 8,9 A 9.9dialkylfluorene unit has previously been used as a building block for constructing donor - acceptor - type conjugated polymers in OPVs such as poly[2,7-(9,9′-dialkylfluorene)-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFDTBT ). PFDTBT showed a maximum PCE of 2.2% , and PFDTBT derivatives containing branched alkyl chains ( BisDMO - PFDTBT ) showed higher PCEs. 10,11 Some molecules and polymers that have flat structures such as fluorene , 12-16 anthracene , 17 and pyrene 18,19 have been reported to form excimers or aggregates by strong interchain π-π interactions. Excimer formation could affect the emission properties of molecules or polymers , therefore , the excimer or exciplex formation has been used as a fluorescence probe for molecular recognition. 19 In organic photovoltaic devices , π-π interactions between low - band gap donor polymers are important for charge transportation. Enhanced π-π interactions in p - type donor polymers could improve their chargetransport ability , and thus increase short - circuit currents in solar cells. In this study we report on a new approach to improve PCE of OPVs by enhancing the interchain π-π interaction. To do this we introduced flat perylene units into the conjugated polymers. We synthesized poly[2,7-(9,9′-dioctylfluorene)-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFDTBT ) , poly[2,2′-(9,9-dioctylfluorene-2,7-diyl)dithiophene-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFD2TBT ) , and their ter-polymers with perylene units. Optical , electrical and photovoltaic properties of the polymers were investigated. Synthetic routes and polymer structures are shown in Schemes 1 and 2 . The UV - visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers were recorded in both chloroform solution and as a solid thin film. PFDTBT and the ter-polymer solutions exhibited two distinct absorption bands , where the first absorption peak is at around 387 nm , corresponding to the π-π* transition of the conjugated polymer backbone , 23,24 and the second absorption band in the longer wavelength region at around 530 nm , can be attributed to the strong internal charge - transfer ( ICT ) interaction between donating and accepting groups in the main chain. 21 Peak and edge positions were almost equivalent for PFDTBT , PFDTBT_5Per and PFDTBT_10Per , but the maximum absorption peak for PFDTBT_20Per moved to a shorter wavelength region. This might be due to a decrease in the internal charge - transfer ( ICT ) interaction cause by a decreased content of electron - withdrawing DTBT monomer in the copolymer. PFD2TBT and the ter-polymer solutions also exhibited two absorption bands at around 410 and 520 nm. The absorption maxima and edges of the polymer solutions showed little dependence upon perylene contents. The UV - visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers in a chloroform solution are shown in Figure 2.

Let's think step by step.

1. PCPDTBT
2. 8,9 A 9.9dialkylfluorene unit
3. PFDTBT
4. PC71BM
5. PFDTBT derivatives
6. BisDMO-PFDTBT
7. Fluorene

11. PFD2TBT
12. PFDTBT_5Per
13. PFDTBT_10Per
14. PFDTBT_20Per
15. PFDTBT, PFDTBT_5Per, PFDTBT_10Per, PFDTBT_20Per (ter-polymers with perylene units)
16. DTBT monomer
17. ICT interaction
18. Donating and accepting groups
19. Charge-transport ability
20. PFDTBT solutions
21. PFD2TBT solutions
22. Chloroform solution
23. Polymer backbone
24. Conjugated polymer backbone
25. Schemes 1 and 2

Note: Some of the entities listed above may be the same material with different names or forms (e.g., PFDTBT and PFDTBT solutions), but they are listed separately for clarity.

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: For ( PCPDTBT ) , which showed absorption in the range 380-900 nm in the AM 1.5 G spectrum , good hole mobility ( 0.01 - 0.1 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ) and a high power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 3.2% with PC71BM as the electron acceptor. 8,9 A 9.9dialkylfluorene unit has previously been used as a building block for constructing donor - acceptor - type conjugated polymers in OPVs such as poly[2,7-(9,9′-dialkylfluorene)-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFDTBT ). PFDTBT showed a maximum PCE of 2.2% , and PFDTBT derivatives containing branched alkyl chains ( BisDMO - PFDTBT ) showed higher PCEs. 10,11 Some molecules and polymers that have flat structures such as fluorene , 12-16 anthracene , 17 and pyrene 18,19 have been reported to form excimers or aggregates by strong interchain π-π interactions. Excimer formation could affect the emission properties of molecules or polymers , therefore , the excimer or exciplex formation has been used as a fluorescence probe for molecular recognition. 19 In organic photovoltaic devices , π-π interactions between low - band gap donor polymers are important for charge transportation. Enhanced π-π interactions in p - type donor polymers could improve their chargetransport ability , and thus increase short - circuit currents in solar cells. In this study we report on a new approach to improve PCE of OPVs by enhancing the interchain π-π interaction. To do this we introduced flat perylene units into the conjugated polymers. We synthesized poly[2,7-(9,9′-dioctylfluorene)-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFDTBT ) , poly[2,2′-(9,9-dioctylfluorene-2,7-diyl)dithiophene-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFD2TBT ) , and their ter-polymers with perylene units. Optical , electrical and photovoltaic properties of the polymers were investigated. Synthetic routes and polymer structures are shown in Schemes 1 and 2 . The UV - visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers were recorded in both chloroform solution and as a solid thin film. PFDTBT and the ter-polymer solutions exhibited two distinct absorption bands , where the first absorption peak is at around 387 nm , corresponding to the π-π* transition of the conjugated polymer backbone , 23,24 and the second absorption band in the longer wavelength region at around 530 nm , can be attributed to the strong internal charge - transfer ( ICT ) interaction between donating and accepting groups in the main chain. 21 Peak and edge positions were almost equivalent for PFDTBT , PFDTBT_5Per and PFDTBT_10Per , but the maximum absorption peak for PFDTBT_20Per moved to a shorter wavelength region. This might be due to a decrease in the internal charge - transfer ( ICT ) interaction cause by a decreased content of electron - withdrawing DTBT monomer in the copolymer. PFD2TBT and the ter-polymer solutions also exhibited two absorption bands at around 410 and 520 nm. The absorption maxima and edges of the polymer solutions showed little dependence upon perylene contents. The UV - visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers in a chloroform solution are shown in Figure 2.

Let's think step by step.

1. PCPDTBT: A specific type of conjugated polymer.
2. AM 1.5 G: A reference spectrum used in photovoltaic research.
3. PCE: Power conversion efficiency.
4. PC71BM: An electron acceptor material.
5. 8,9 A 9.9dialkylfluorene unit: A building block for constructing donor-acceptor type conjugated polymers.
6. PFDTBT: A specific conjugated polymer with a maximum PCE of 2.2%.
7. BisDMO-PFDTBT: A derivative of PFDTBT with branched alkyl chains.
8. Fluorene: A molecule with a flat structure.
9. Anthracene: A molecule with a flat structure.
10. Pyrene: A molecule with a flat structure.
11. PFDTBT: A specific conjugated polymer.
12. PFD2TBT: A specific conjugated polymer.
13. Ter-polymers: Three-component polymers.
14. Perylene units: Flat aromatic structures introduced into the conjugated polymers.
15. Schemes 1 and 2: Diagrams illustrating the synthetic routes and polymer structures.
16. Chloroform: A solvent used for recording UV-visible absorption spectra.
17. UV-visible absorption spectra: Measurements of the amount of light absorbed as a function of wavelength.
18. First absorption peak: The first distinct absorption band in the UV-visible absorption spectrum.
19. Second absorption band: The second distinct absorption band in the UV-visible absorption spectrum.
20. π-π* transition: An electronic transition involving the transfer of an electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) within the same molecule.
21. Internal charge transfer (ICT) interaction: The transfer of an electron from a donor to an acceptor within the same molecule or between neighboring molecules.
22. Donating groups: Groups that donate electrons.
23. Accepting groups: Groups that accept electrons.
24. Main chain: The backbone of the conjugated polymer.
25. Perylene units: Flat aromatic structures introduced into the conjugated polymers.
26. Copolymer: A polymer made up of two or more different monomers.
27. DTBT monomer: A specific monomer in the copolymer.
28. Figure 2: A diagram or graph showing the UV-visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers in a chloroform solution.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. PCPDTBT: Conjugated polymer.
2. PCE: Power conversion efficiency.
3. PC71BM: Electron acceptor material.
4. PFDTBT: Conjugated polymer with a maximum PCE of 2.2%.
5. Fluorene: Molecule.
6. Anthracene: Molecule.
7. Pyrene: Molecule.
8. PFDTBT: Conjugated polymer.
9. PFD2TBT: Conjugated polymer.
10. Perylene units: Flat aromatic structures.
11. ICT interaction: Internal charge transfer interaction.
12. Donating groups: Electron donor groups.
13. Accepting groups: Electron accepting groups.
14. DTBT monomer: Monomer in the copolymer.
15. Copolymer: Polymer made up of two or more different monomers.
16. First absorption peak: Distinct absorption band in the UV-visible absorption spectrum, corresponding to the π-π* transition of the conjugated polymer backbone.
17. Second absorption band: Distinct absorption band in the UV-visible absorption spectrum, attributed to the strong internal charge transfer (ICT) interaction between donating and accepting groups in the main chain.
18. Maximum absorption peak: The peak with the highest absorption in the UV-visible absorption spectrum.
19. Content of electron-withdrawing DTBT monomer: The amount of the electron-withdrawing DTBT monomer in the copolymer.

Paragraph: For ( PCPDTBT ) , which showed absorption in the range 380-900 nm in the AM 1.5 G spectrum , good hole mobility ( 0.01 - 0.1 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ) and a high power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 3.2% with PC71BM as the electron acceptor. 8,9 A 9.9dialkylfluorene unit has previously been used as a building block for constructing donor - acceptor - type conjugated polymers in OPVs such as poly[2,7-(9,9′-dialkylfluorene)-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFDTBT ). PFDTBT showed a maximum PCE of 2.2% , and PFDTBT derivatives containing branched alkyl chains ( BisDMO - PFDTBT ) showed higher PCEs. 10,11 Some molecules and polymers that have flat structures such as fluorene , 12-16 anthracene , 17 and pyrene 18,19 have been reported to form excimers or aggregates by strong interchain π-π interactions. Excimer formation could affect the emission properties of molecules or polymers , therefore , the excimer or exciplex formation has been used as a fluorescence probe for molecular recognition. 19 In organic photovoltaic devices , π-π interactions between low - band gap donor polymers are important for charge transportation. Enhanced π-π interactions in p - type donor polymers could improve their chargetransport ability , and thus increase short - circuit currents in solar cells. In this study we report on a new approach to improve PCE of OPVs by enhancing the interchain π-π interaction. To do this we introduced flat perylene units into the conjugated polymers. We synthesized poly[2,7-(9,9′-dioctylfluorene)-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFDTBT ) , poly[2,2′-(9,9-dioctylfluorene-2,7-diyl)dithiophene-alt-5,5′-(4′,7′-di-2-thienyl-2′,1′,3′-benzothiadiazole)] ( PFD2TBT ) , and their ter-polymers with perylene units. Optical , electrical and photovoltaic properties of the polymers were investigated. Synthetic routes and polymer structures are shown in Schemes 1 and 2 . The UV - visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers were recorded in both chloroform solution and as a solid thin film. PFDTBT and the ter-polymer solutions exhibited two distinct absorption bands , where the first absorption peak is at around 387 nm , corresponding to the π-π* transition of the conjugated polymer backbone , 23,24 and the second absorption band in the longer wavelength region at around 530 nm , can be attributed to the strong internal charge - transfer ( ICT ) interaction between donating and accepting groups in the main chain. 21 Peak and edge positions were almost equivalent for PFDTBT , PFDTBT_5Per and PFDTBT_10Per , but the maximum absorption peak for PFDTBT_20Per moved to a shorter wavelength region. This might be due to a decrease in the internal charge - transfer ( ICT ) interaction cause by a decreased content of electron - withdrawing DTBT monomer in the copolymer. The absorption maxima and edges of the polymer solutions showed little dependence upon perylene contents. Let's think step by step.

1. For PCPDTBT:
- Absorption in the range 380-900 nm in the AM 1.5 G spectrum
- Hole mobility: 0.01 - 0.1 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
- Power conversion efficiency (PCE): 3.2%

2. For PFDTBT:
- Maximum PCE: 2.2%

3. For BisDMO-PFDTBT:
- Higher PCEs than PFDTBT

4. For fluorene, anthracene, pyrene, and perylene:
- Reported to form excimers or aggregates by strong interchain π-π interactions

5. In organic photovoltaic devices:
- Important for charge transportation: π-π interactions between low-band gap donor polymers
- Enhanced π-π interactions in p-type donor polymers could improve charge transport ability

6. New approach to improve PCE of OPVs:
- Introduce flat perylene units into the conjugated polymers

7. Synthesized polymers:
- PFDTBT, PFD2TBT, and their ter-polymers with perylene units

8. UV-visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers:
- PFDTBT and ter-polymer solutions exhibit two distinct absorption bands
  - First absorption peak: around 387 nm (π-π* transition of the conjugated polymer backbone)
  - Second absorption band: in the longer wavelength region, around 530 nm (strong internal charge transfer interaction between donating and accepting groups in the main chain)
- PFD2TBT and ter-polymer solutions also exhibit two absorption bands at around 410 and 520 nm
- Peak and edge positions of the polymer solutions showed little dependence upon perylene contents

9. UV-visible absorption spectra of the synthesized polymers in a chloroform solution:
- Shown in Figure 2

10. PFDTBT, PFDTBT_5Per, and PFDTBT_10Per:
- Maximum absorption peak for PFDTBT_20Per moved to a shorter wavelength region
- This might be due to a decrease in the internal charge transfer interaction caused by a decreased content of electron-withdrawing DTBT monomer in the copolymer.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. For PCPDTBT:
- Absorption range: 380-900 nm (AM 1.5 G spectrum)
- Hole mobility: 0.01 - 0.1 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
- Power conversion efficiency (PCE): 3.2%

2. For PFDTBT:
- Maximum PCE: 2.2%

3. For synthesized polymers:
- PFDTBT, PFD2TBT, and their ter-polymers with perylene units:
  - Absorption peak 1: around 387 nm (π-π* transition of the conjugated polymer backbone)
  - Absorption peak 2: around 530 nm (strong internal charge transfer interaction between donating and accepting groups in the main chain) or around 520 nm (for PFD2TBT and ter-polymers)

4. For PFDTBT_20Per:
- Maximum absorption peak: shorter wavelength region (decreased content of electron-withdrawing DTBT monomer in the copolymer)
